Graphical abstract Various interlayers developed recently for inserting between the cathode and the anode of Li-S batteries to improve the energy storage performance have been discussed and analyzed. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have great potential in next-generation energy storage due to its high theoretical specific capacity and energy density. However, there are several challenges to the practical application of Li-S batteries including the growth of lithium dendrites and the shuttle effect of polysulfide. Introducing interlayeres (freestanding or coated on the separator) is an effective approach to reduce these obstacles and improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. In this review, we briefly summarize the interlayer materials and structures modified on both cathodic and anodic sides including (i) carbon-based materials, (ii) polymers, (iii) inorganic metal compounds, (iv) metal–organic frameworks, as well as (v) the novel separators in recent years. We also systematically address the fabrication processes, assembling methods, and functions of interlayers for enhancing the performance of Li-S batteries. Furthermore, the prospects and outlooks of the future development of advanced interlayers and separators are also presented. Keywords Li-S battery Interlayer Separator Polysulfide Dendrite 1 Introduction The development and utilization of clean energy have been considered as a promising strategy to deal with environmental pollution and the energy crisis. However, natural clean energy sources, such as solar and wind power, usually demonstrate an intermittent nature and depend much on the external conditions [1–7]. In this context, energy storage devices, especially rechargeable batteries that can collect different types of energy and release them whenever needed are attracting extensive interest all over the world. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery is one of the most promising post-lithium-ion batteries with lithium plate as the anode and sulfur as the cathode materials. During the discharging process, the lithium metal is oxidized to lithium ions (Li+ ions) at the anode (Anode reaction: L i → L i + + e - ). While at the cathode, sulfur is reduced to S2− via different polysulfide species, such as Li2S8, Li2S6, and Li2S4 (Cathode reaction: S + 2 e - → S 2 - ). The charging process undergoes an opposite reaction [8–11]. Li-S battery has several advantages comparing with other rechargeable batteries. For instance: (i) Sulfur is environmentally friendly and naturally abundant on the earth; (ii) sulfur has a high theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g−1 and a high energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 [12–19]. However, there are some notable obstacles should be overcome before using sulfur as the electrode material. For example, sulfur is not only electrically insulative but also has a considerable volume change in the charge/discharge process. The migration of intermediate polysulfide usually leads to a considerable loss of sulfur, resulting in poor cycling performance and rate capability [20,21]. To solve these problems, porous and conductive materials with characteristic adsorption to polysulfide have been comprehensively studied as the support of cathode [22–24]. With these efforts, the suppression of the shuttle effect, the electrochemical reaction kinetics, and the overall battery performance have seen significant improvement [25–27]. In addition to the electrode modification, introducing certain interlayer between separator and electrode, or designing appropriate separator provides an alternative, yet effective approach to improve the electrochemical properties of Li-S batteries [28–31]. In general, interlayer in the cathode side is expected to inhibit the shuttling of lithium polysulfide, promote the polysulfide conversion and hence improve the utilization of sulfur and enhance the capacity and cycling performance of battery [32–35]. Therefore, when designing a cathodic interlayer, several requirements should be noted. For instance, effective interception of polysulfide shuttling, good electrolyte affinity, and high Li+ ion transport efficiency [36]. In the anode side, dendritic lithium growth during the deposition/stripping cycle leads to repeated fracture and reconstruction of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) membrane and continuous consumption of lithium and electrolyte. What's more, the lithium dendrite poses a risk of penetrating the separator, causing an internal short-circuit and even a catastrophic safety issue [37]. Thus, the designing of an anodic interlayer should focus on the functions of inhibiting dendrite growth, protecting lithium anode, and promoting the uniform deposition of lithium. A separator in the Li-S battery can not only prevent the direct contact of cathode and anode, but also offer the transmission channels for Li+ ions [38–41]. The modification on separator plays a similar role to the anodic/cathodic interlayer, and mainly by changing the pore size and structure of the separator. That is, interlayer science and engineering are contributive and important to high performance Li-S batteries. In this review, we summarize the different interlayers introduced on both cathodic and anodic sides that have been developed in recent years, present a full picture of advanced interlayers with well-designed structures and compositions, and analyze their contributions to the electrochemical properties of the resultant Li-S batteries. Besides, some newly designed separators with novel materials are also discussed to provide an overview of the sulfur-fixing technologies developed in the field of Li-S battery. 2 Cathodic interlayer Various interlayers are discussed in this part whether serving as a freestanding interlayer or being coated onto separators toward the cathodic side. A schematic illustration showing the structure and composition of a Li-S battery is demonstrated in Fig. 1 . The cathodic interlayer acts as a barrier outside the cathode to deal with the problem of polysulfide shuttling and conversion. Polysulfides that have passed through the separator are opportunistic to react with lithium metal, or convert into dissoluble lithium sulfide and stay at the anodic side, which will cause the loss of active materials and the decline of battery capacity. In this section, we summarize the interlayer materials that have been successfully employed at the cathodic side of Li-S batteries, such as carbon materials, polymers, inorganic metal compounds (mainly oxides, sulfides, nitrides), as well as metal–organic frameworks [42–44]. 2.1 Carbon materials Introducing a carbon interlayer between the cathode and separator is a widely-used method to hinder the migration of polysulfide [45–47]. The carbon material serves as an upper current collector to provide more active sites for electron transfer, and thus enhance the utilization of active materials [48]. Various carbon-based materials, such as carbon nanotube (CNT) [49], graphene [50], porous carbon [51], carbon nanofiber (CNF) [52], etc. have been employed to coat separators or adopted as freestanding interlayers. 2.1.1 Carbon nanotube More than a decade has passed since the CNT interlayer was applied in Li-S batteries. Flexible interlayers with single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) or multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) have excellent electrical conductivity and mechanical flexibility, thus were able to buffer the large volumetric change of sulfur during the charge/discharge process without bringing in obvious additional impedance [53,54]. CNT interlayer can restrict the diffusion of polysulfide via physical obstructing, while guest materials incorporation can exert chemical bonding with polysulfide which is proved to be more effective in improving the cycling stability of Li-S batteries. In the following text, pure CNT interlayer and CNT composite interlayers will be discussed. As early as 2012, professor Manthiram et al. proposed a freestanding MWCNT paper as an interlayer for Li-S batteries. The porous MWCNT paper can absorb the po lysulfides and prevent their shuttling via physical restriction. The charge transfer resistance of the sulfur electrode was greatly reduced due to the high electron conductivity of the inserted CNT interlayer [53]. Since then, the investigation of CNT-based Li-S battery interlayers attracted extensive interest in the scientific community, and the interlayer study in the field of Li-S batteries developed rapidly. In 2018, Manoj et al. inserted a freestanding pure CNT interlayer between the separator and the polyaniline/mesoporous carbon-supported sulfur cathode (Fig. 2 (a)) [49]. The conductive porous CNT interlayer acts as a pseudo-upper current collector that can help facilitate the localization of polysulfide within the cathode region through the interconnected network structure. As shown in Fig. 2(b and c), with the insertion of a CNT interlayer, an obvious increase in the redox peak is observed, which is credible evidence of higher sulfur utilization. Moreover, a slight shift and broadening of the current peaks reflect the rapid conversion between sulfide and sulfur during the scanning process, and that has been credited to the increased conductivity brought by CNT interlayer. Therefore, the shuttling of polysulfide was hindered and the conversion of polysulfide was promoted. As a result, the as-designed Li-S battery with the CNT interlayer exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 1137 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C. As the current density increased to 1 C, the battery delivered a discharge capacity of 968 mAh g−1 at the initial cycle and remained at 700 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. In contrast, the initial discharge capacity of the Li-S battery without CNT interlayer was ~600 mAh g−1, which is far less than that of Li-S batteries with CNT interlayers. CNT network-based interlayers restrain polysulfide and help promote their conversion via mostly physical confinement. However, chemical adsorption has been proved to capture sulfur with higher efficiency. Thus, various sulfur fixing components that can exert strong chemical adsorption to polysulfide have been incorporated into CNT structures to serve as composite interlayers. For example, heteroatoms, such as oxygen or phosphorus modified carbon structures have demonstrated a positive effect in sulfur fixing in Li-S batteries [56,57]. In 2018, Kim et al. carried out thermal treatments on CNTs under oxygen atmosphere to enhance the electrochemical performance of the resultant Li-S batteries with CNT interlayers [56]. The O contents of oxygen-treated CNT (O-CNT) and pristine CNT were determined to be 14.63% and 6.92%, respectively. The significantly improved cycling stability proved that the O-CNT interlayer inhibited the shuttling of negatively charged polysulfide through both physical restriction and electrostatic repulsion. As a result, the sulfur cathode with an O-CNT interlayer revealed the capacity retention of 70.3% over 250 cycles at 0.5 C, while the reference cathode without interlayer only maintained 26.5% capacity through the same charge/discharge measurement. CNT-based compounds holding specific atoms that have characteristic interaction with the sulfur species via chemical bonding showed remarkable ability in preventing shuttle effect, and thus have been frequently used as an effective component in interlayers [58,59]. For example, an ultrathin and lightweight CNT/MoS2 interlayer coated polypropylene separator was introduced to a well-designed Li-S battery (Fig. 2(d)) [55]. The conductive CNT network facilitated the charge transfer kinetics and the fast conversion between Li2S/Li2S2 and the sulfur species, while the MoS2 nanosheets helped restrict the polysulfide diffusion via chemical interaction. And thus, the resultant Li-S batteries exhibited an excellent rate capability comparing with the cell with a pristine separator (no interlayer coatings) (Fig. 2(e)). Moreover, the self-discharge was dramatically suppressed by inserting a CNT/MoS2 interlayer as demonstrated by the fact that the cells rested for 5 hours after the 5th cycle showed 15.6% and 60.7% capacity decay in the cases of with and without interlayers, respectively (Fig. 2(f)). It is well-known that the self-discharge resulted from the shuttle effect is one of the major drawbacks of Li-S batteries and substantial efforts have been exerted to solve this problem. In this work, a CNT/MoS2 interlayer was proved effective in suppressing the self-discharge due to the inherent high conductivity and outstanding polysulfide trapping capability, which provided an alternative approach for high performance Li-S batteries with extended shelf-lives. Therefore, one can see that the one-dimensional CNT assembled interlayer is porous and flexible that is capable of addressing the problems of volume change and poor conductivity of sulfur cathode besides physically suppressing the shuttle effect. The porous nature of the CNT skeleton further renders its robust support for the incorporation of other functional additives to enhance the sulfur fixing ability and polysulfide conversion efficiency [60]. Functionalized CNTs with specific adsorption to sulfur species are more preferable to be employed due to the significantly enhanced polysulfide capturing efficiency. Thus, the CNT-based interlayers have attracted wide interest and have been widely investigated as one of the most promising Li-S battery interlayer materials. 2.1.2 Graphene Graphene-related materials are widely used in electrochemical energy storage devices because of their excellent mechanical flexibility, large surface area, and high electrical conductivities [61], which can offer plenty of ion-transport channels during electrochemical kinetic processes and act as a polysulfide physical barrier when employed in Li-S batteries. Moreover, when functional groups or foreign components are introduced into the graphene system, chemical adsorption to the polysulfide will bring in an improved sulfur-capturing capability [62]. As a result, graphene-related materials including graphene oxide (GO), graphene, as well as graphene-based composite have been employed as the interlayers for Li-S batteries. Graphene oxide is a kind of oxygen-containing graphene material that has demonstrated a strong chemical interaction with polysulfide. With the attachment of oxygen-containing groups, foreign components are more easily to incorporate into the graphene structure to enhance the sulfur-fixing capability and help promote the conversion of polysulfide. For examp le, Wu et al. designed a “releasing and binding” method to prepare a 3D hierarchical porous N-doped graphene (NG) as the interlayer of a Li-S battery (Fig. 3 (a)) [61]. In this report, a mixed solution with GO, pyrrole, and urea was first sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave. After a hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for 12 h, the sample was collected and annealed at 1000 °C to prepare the NG structure. The product marked as PXNG (x is the amount of pyrrole) was further coated onto a PP separator and employed as an interlayer. In this approach, N atoms were demonstrated in promoting the adsorption of sulfur in the cathodic side. While the composite 3D interlayer not only offered better electronic pathways between the insulating sulfur and the discharging product, but also helped prevent large amounts of lithium polysulfide intermediate from migrating to the Li metal anode. Thus, the SEI film formed on the anode can be denser and more compact that will benefit less Li corrosion in the electrochemical process and a long lifespan battery. As a result, the Li-S battery with a P0.4NG interlayer demonstrated a high initial capacity of 1150.3 mAh g−1, and stabilized at 851.8 mAh g−1 over 200 cycles (Fig. 3(b)). Comparing with the pristine sulfur cathode without interlayers, the P0.4NG interlayer also improved the rate capabilities of the Li-S battery in the range of 0.1–2 C that was superior to the case of no interlayer was used (Fig. 3(c)). Except for single element doping, dual-doping has also been reported in graphene-based interlayers. For example, N, S-codoped graphene (NSG) sponge was prepared by Xing et al. and used as an electroactive interlayer in Li-S batteries [47]. The synthesis involved an oil bath at 90 °C to treat the mixture of thiocarbohydrazide and GO. The resultant hydrogel was lyophilized to give out an NSG structure which demonstrated as a hierarchically porous sponge. The N and S co-doping was found to enhance the binding between polysulfide and graphene sheet via cooperative and strong chemical adsorption. Moreover, as the heteroatom doping ratio increased, a better sulfur-fixing ability and a larger battery capacity were observed in the subsequent cycles. For example, a certain amount of GO suspension was doped with 25 mg (NSG-1) and 250 mg (NSG-10) thiocarbohydrazide, respectively. Results showed that the Li-S battery with an NSG-10 interlayer delivered an initial discharge capacity of 1800 mAh g−1, while the NSG-1 interlayer only approved the capacity of ~1200 mAh g−1. The combination of GO and CNT can not only trap sulfur species by both physical restriction and chemical adsorption, but also offer a high porosity and a high electrical conductivity for fast ion and electron transfer. For example, Huang and co-workers used a freestanding and porous GO/CNT hybrid film between the cathode and the Celgard 2400 separator of Li-S batteries [63]. With the GO/CNT ratio of 1:2, the interlayer film demonstrated the highest surface area and the best electrochemical performance that rendered the sulfur cathode a high initial capacity of 1370 mAh g−1. The GO/CNT (70 wt%) mixture and PVDF binder (30 wt%) composite were also coated onto a polypropylene (PP) separator as an integrated interlayer [64], which suppressed the migration of polysulfide effectively during the charge/discharge process as confirmed by EDS result that less sulfur distribution on the Li anode over 200 cycles was observed. The blocking function of the CO/CNT interlayer in this design not only provided an effective inhibition for polysulfide migration but also promoted the rapid transfer of electrons and Li+ ions, ensured a stable cycling performance and a long cycle life. The chemical reducing treatment to GO usually leads to a partial restoration of oxygen-engaged defective sites, and a significantly enhanced electrical conductivity. The resultant lamellar structure in the reduced graphene oxide (rGO) can further block the transmission of polysulfide, promoting the conversion of polysulfide and improve the utilization of sulfur materials. Moreover, the reduction process can be proceeded with the incorporation of the certain foreign component to improve the sulfur-fixing capability [65,66]. For example, Tan et al. synthesized rGO/MoS2 composite by a one-step hydrothermal method using composite precursors of GO, sodium molybdate dehydrate and sulfourea [67]. The rGO/MoS2 was coated onto the separator of a Li-S battery via the vacuum-filtration process. As a result, the rGO/MoS2 interlayer demonstrated a remarkable capability in suppressing the diffusion of polysulfide due to the synergetic effect of both physical blocking from the porous carbon structure and chemical adsorption from MoS2 and the defective sites in rGO. Therefore, a high initial specific capacity of 1121 mAh g−1 and a low capacity fading rate of 0.116% per cycle over 500 cycles at 1 C were achieved. In conclusion, graphene-based materials are efficient to chemically immobilize the polysulfide due to the attached functional groups and the easy incorporation of foreign component beyond the normal physical restriction effect. Both of GO- and rGO-based interlayers have demonstrated great capabilities in enhancing the utilization of sulfur and improving the electrochemical kinetics. Thus, they are promising candidates for the interlayer materials of advanced Li-S batteries. 2.1.3 Other carbon materials Except for the widely used CNT and graphene, other carbon-based materials like Super P, acetylene black, carbon paper/cloth, carbon foam, have also been studied as the interlayers to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. For example, commercially available carbon powder super P is commonly used as a conductive additive in the research of materials science. Recently, super P has also been tried as the interlayer component in Li-S batteries. Recently, Zhang et al. prepared a super P and PVDF mixture and coated them on the cathodic side of a PP separator [68]. The SEM image showed that the porous surface of the separator may provide a facile pathway for ion movement. The porous super P/PVDF coating interlayer functioned not only as an absorbent to immobilize the migration of polysulfide but also as an upper current collector in facilitating electron transfer, as well as an activation agent to promote the conversion of the trapped active materials. Consequently, the resultant Li-S cells with this modified separator revealed a high specific capacity of 778 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C over 100 cycles. Acetylene black and gelatin with a weight ratio of 4:1 were utilized to coat PP separator in Li-S batteries with the cathode composed of sulfur, acetylene black, and gelatin [69]. In this well-designed interlayer, the carbon component contributed to reutilize the dissolved sulfur species and reduce the internal charge transfer resistance to 96 Ω, while the gelatin promoted the electrolyte infiltration through separators. Therefore, the resultant Li-S battery containing this interlayer delivered a stabilized and reversible capacity of 762 mAh g−1 at 0.2C. Carbon cloth-based interlayer supported with tungsten disulfide (WS2) nanoparticles was also employed as a functional interlayer for Li-S batteries [70]. Due to that the WS2 is an effective catalyst for hydrodesulphurization and its strong adsorption to sulfur and sulfides, this interlayer not only provided effective adsorption to polysulfide but also ensured a fast electron transfer process between the cathode and polysulfide. As a result, after 100 cycles at 0.05 C, the capacity retention ratios of the cells without modification, with WS2, with carbon cloth, with WS2 and carbon cloth were 27.5%, 31.6%, 62.3%, and 80.4%, respectively. Manthiram et al. prepared a microporous carbon paper (MCP) as a bifunctional interlayer for Li-S battery [71]. The battery with MCP maintained a capacity of 846 mAh g−1 for 70 cycles at 3 C and retained over 1000 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles at 1 C, rendering an average Coulombic efficiency of 97.6%. The excellent electrochemical performance was ascribed to the good contact between the cathode surface and the flexible carbon paper, which accommodated the migration of polysulfide intermediate by providing an electronic channel for the insulator S/Li2S. The interlayer with micro/mesoporous pores served as an upper collector to improve the utilization of sulfur and as a reservoir for the residence of polysulfide to maintain capacity. The strategy also held the potential to be extended to other lightweight conductive/porous interlayers for further improvement of Li-S batteries. In another case, flexible N-doped carbon foam monolith synthesized from pyrolysis of polyurethane foam has demonstrated a prominent sulfur-capturing ability [72]. The carbonized 3D N-doped porous carbon networks demonstrated excellent flexibility and high electrical conductivity. With the cathode materials fabricated from CNTs and sulfur in the mass ratio of 1:1.5, the resultant battery with the carbon foam interlayer exhibited a stable capacity of 902.8 mAh g−1 over 100 cycles at 0.5 C. The improvement in cell performance was attributed to the porous structure of the interlayer for the following reasons: (i) Li+ ions and polysulfide generated during charging and discharging were easier to migrate or redistribute; (ii) large voids that could accommodate the expansion of sulfur; (iii) the multilayer structure provided an efficient and conductive network at the nanoscale that had a strong adsorption capacity to prevent the dissolution of polysulfide. In addition, the doping of heteroatomic N and the abundance of surface functional groups led to an improvement of surface adsorption capability due to the strong interatomic attraction between pyridine N and polysulfide. Carbon materials have been employed for battery interlayers relatively early. CNT and graphene as two kinds of important materials that brought significant changes in battery systems including not only cathodes but also interlayers for Li-S batteries. They are proper candidates to collect current and reactivate “dead sulfur” in Li-S batteries, and thus they are extensively studied in blending with sulfur at the cathode to rescue the active materials that escaped from the cathode side [73,74] . Although the carbon interlayers were light-weighted and conductive, their interaction with the polysulfide is mainly physical confinement, which is relatively weak and should be improved. Heteroatoms doping (N, O, S, P, etc.) or combining with the foreign component which owns a strong sulfur immobilization ability could be a remedy. Therefore, one can see that most of the carbon-based interlayers are involved with secondary or more components to enhance electrochemical performance (Table 1 ). The synergetic contribution of carbon materials with high conductivity and other incorporations with strong adsorption to polysulfide is a major advancement of the Li-S battery system. 2.2 Polymers Polymer-modified separator and freestanding polymer-based interlayer are helpful to maintain high Columbic efficiency and high-rate performance of Li-S battery due to the outstanding sulfur-fixing capability originated from the functional group attached in the molecular chain. Polymers with good thermal and chemical stability are favorable to be utilized as the additional layers in Li-S batteries. Although most of the polymers are insulating that is not favorable for fast electron transfer and catalytic conversion, both non-conductive and conductive polymers have been investigated in the field of Li-S battery interlayers. Due to the existence of flexible molecular chains and abundant amino and hydroxyl groups, polydopamine (PDA) has been explored in Li-S battery to accommodate the volume change of sulfur and restrict the shuttling of sulfur species [78]. For instance, Huang et al. introduced a PDA porous film coated separator into a Li-S battery (Fig. 4 (a)), which further acted as a physical barrier to block the diffusion of polysulfide [75]. In addition, both catechol and amine groups in dopamine are beneficial to facilitate the electrolyte uptake and ionic conductivity besides sulfur fixing. The highly hydrophilic chemical component retarded the electrolyte diffusion, and thus a large amount of polysulfide anion was trapped by the PDA coating. As a result, the Li-S cell with PDA-coated separator exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 885 mAh g−1, and a specific discharge capacity of 670 mAh g−1 over 200 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 4(b)), which was superior to those of a routine separator without the PDA-based interlayer. In another case, Li et al. reported improved electrochemical performance of Li-S battery with PDA-modified separator prepared by an auto-oxidization and self-polymerization method [79]. The resultant cell delivered an even higher initial capacity of 1271 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, and 1020.3 mAh g−1 was maintained after 30 cycles. Nafion membrane has plenty of SO3 − groups which will bounce the polysulfide anions by electrostatic repulsion and decrease the loss of sulfur. It is worth noting that the thickness of the Nafion layer is rather important when used as the interlayer of Li-S battery. For example, Kim et al. proposed an improved Nafion nanoweb that has an efficient permeation efficiency for Li+ ions and a good electrolyte wettability [76]. The Nafion-based blocking layer was prepared by electrospinning polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and Nafion solution onto the sulfur cathode. The resultant composite cathode with the aid of the Nafion/PVP nanoweb layer exhibited not only a superior rate performance but also a higher remaining capacity of 695 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 4(c and d)). In contrast, the sulfur cathode with a compact Nafion layer had an inferior rate capability from 0.5 to 2 C than the bare sulfur cathode, which was ascribed to the limited Li+ ion transfer because the electrolyte could spread out on the surface of the Nafion/PVP nanoweb, while the contact angle of the same electrolyte on a dense Nafion layer was only 15.6°. Babu et al. further studied the modified separator that was coated with a mixture of Nafion and sulfonated polyetheretherketone (SPEEK) [80]. A SPEEK molecule also has a large amount of SO3 − ions, possessing an excellent permission selectivity as Nafion film. In addition, a SPEEK demonstrates a superior chemical and thermal stability to those of Nafion. Therefore, in this study, Nafion and SPEEK were mixed at different ratios and drop-casted onto the separator. At the optimized ratio of 1:1, a capacity of 600 mAh g−1 was achieved at 0.2 C over 300 cycles. Moreover, the extended result revealed that the electrochemical performance of a Li-S battery can be further improved by placing another freestanding SPEEK/Nafion layer at the cathodic side. Li-S batteries with polymer-coated CNT-based interlayer demonstrated an excellent cycling performance than polymer or CNT only interlayers [81]. For example, Kim et al. reported a slower battery capacity decay with poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) coated CNT composite interlayer comparing with that of cells with CNT the only interlayer. At 1 C rate, the sulfur cathode with CNT interlayer showed 57% capacity retention after 200 cycles, while the cathode with a PAA/SWCNT interlayer maintained 74.4%. The conductive CNT in the interlayer resulted in the increased utilization of sulfur and the improved redox reaction kinetics. The chemical binding between PAA and Li2S8 further strengthened the fixing of sulfur species. Therefore, the combination of PAA and SWCNT in the interlayer efficiently confined the polysulfide species within the cathode area and facilitated the reversible electrochemical process, leading to an enhanced rate capability and cycling stability. Cyclized-polyacrylonitrile (PAN) membrane with abundant C=N bonds has also been attempted to capture polysulfide in Li-S batteries. For example, a multi-functional interlayer composed of a cyclized-PAN network and CNF skeleton has been proposed by Li et al. [82] The fabrication of this interlayer involves electrospinning a concentrated PAN solution on a CNF structure and subsequently thermal treating the composite to prepare a cyclized-PAN coated CNF structure. The highly conductive (10 S cm−1) 3D porous carbon network provided numerous effective transfer channels for electrons and ions, while the abundant pyridine groups in the PAN matrix can further entrap polysulfide via strong inter-atomic attraction. The Li-S battery with this interlayer showed an improved initial capacity of 1479 mAh g−1 compared to the 1096 mAh g−1 for battery with pure CNF interlayer, and a high capacity retention of 85.1% after 100 cycles at 0.3 C was achieved. Conductive polymers have recently received broad attention in the field of Li-S battery due to that they can provide both high electronic and high ionic conductivities. For instance, Ma et al. synthesized a freestanding PPy nanotube film (PNTF) and placed it between the cathode and separator [83]. Owing to the highly conductive, large surface area of PPy nanotube and its strong chemical absorption to polysulfide, the resultant battery displayed a lower charge plateau and a higher discharge plateau, indicating a decreased polarization of sulfur cathode comparing to the cells without PNTF interlayers. Moreover, the shuttle effect was sufficiently suppressed and the active material was redistributed in the charge/discharge process. Therefore, a high initial discharge capacity of 1102 mAh g−1 was achieved at 0.5 C with a sulfur loading of 2.5–3.0 mg cm−2. Polysulfide species are supposed to be immobilized by the hydrogen bond between sulfur and PPy molecule due to that a PPy is usually proton-doped. Later, they further investigated the electrochemical properties of different Li-S cells with the separators modified by PPy nanotube, PPy nanowire, and reduced graphene oxide, respectively [84]. Owing to the stronger interaction between PPy and sulfide, as well as the better wettability of PPy with electrolyte, the resultant cells with PPy (nanotube and nanowire) modified separators exhibited both higher Coulombic efficiency and better cycling performance than those of cells with rGO modified separator. Yin et al. investigated the electrochemical contribution of polyaniline/graphene oxide (PANI/GO) interlayer in Li-S batteries [77]. The GO was prepared by a modified Hummers' method, followed by filtration of GO dispersion to synthesize a GO paper, which was subsequently immersed in a mixed solution to prepare a PANI-deposited GO paper (Fig. 4(e and f)). With the addition of this PANI/GO interlayer, the cathode of Ketjen black/S, super P, and PVDF composite delivered an initial capacity of 1261 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, and the capacity retention reached to 73% after 150 cycles. As the current density changed from 0.1 to 0.2, 0.5, 1 C, the initial discharge capacities changed from 1421 to 1212, 1103, 1048 mAh g−1, respectively. Impressively, as the current density returned to 0.2 C, the capacity recovered to 1155 mAh g−1, which was superior to those of the other Li-S cells with bare GO interlayer or pristine separator (Fig. 4(g)). Such performance enhancement was attributed to the chemical interaction between the polysulfide and the imine group of a quinoid ring in PANI that ensured the immobilization of sulfide species in the cathodic side and a high sulfur utilization rate. Moreover, the average conductivity of the PANI/GO interlayer was determined to be 6.62 × 10−3 S cm−1, which is secure to provide a fast electron transport channel to initiate an impressive rate performance. In summary, non-conductive polymers with ion-selective functions (Nafion or conductive polymers like PPy, PANI) have been proved effective in enhancing the capacity, lifespan, and rate capability of Li-S batteries (Table. 2 ). However, as reported in the literature, it is insufficient to simply distinguish the pore sizes as micropore, mesopore and macropore, the reasonable regulation of pore structure and pore distribution in the interlayer would be more helpful to establish the fundamental issues in Li-S batteries [85]. Thus, the exploring of polymer-based interlayer materials with high polysulfide immobilization and high electrochemical properties are still on the way. 2.3 Inorganic metal compounds It is generally accepted that many metal-based inorganic materials, like metal oxides, metal sulfides or metal nitrides, etc. can provide a strong chemical absorption to the polysulfide due to the strong polarity. However, the electrical conductivity of most inorganic metal compounds is poor. While combining with electrically conductive, porous, and lightweight carbon material has been a widely accepted remedy. This kind of composite materials can not only solve the kinetic problem during the electrochemical process but also display strong chemical adsorption capability to sulfur species. Appropriate metal oxides can form chemical bonds with polysulfide or transform them into S2O3 2− to facilitate the capturing of sulfur-based active materials [86]. While some metal oxides can further accelerate the electrochemical kinetic process by promoting the conversion of polysulfide [87,88]. For example, a hollow spherical La2O3 was fabricated from the spray-granulation method and further spread on a routine separator to form a La2O3-coated separator [87]. Electrochemical measurement demonstrated that the battery with a La2O3 coating layer showed great advantages in terms of cycling stability, rate capability, and fast kinetic reaction because the hollow spherical La2O3 layer served as not only a physical shield to alleviate polysulfide shuttling but also a chemical catalyzer to accelerate the sulfur-sulfide redox reaction. Therefore, charge/discharge results revealed that the Li-S cell with a La2O3-coated separator delivered an initial capacity of 966 mAh g−1 at 1 C and maintained a discharge capacity of 720 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles, comparing with ~400 mAh g−1 (200 cycles later from the initial 720 mAh g−1) in the case of a routine separator was used. Metal oxide-based composite interlayers are also extensively investigated aiming at integrating the advantages of different parties, like Mo- or Fe-based carbon composites [91–93]. For example, Zhuang et al. reported the fabrication of a MoO2/CNF membrane interlayer by a facile electrospinning technology, and they were explored in the electrochemical process of a Li-S battery [89]. TEM test revealed the MoO2/CNF in the interlayer consisted of mainly lined particles and crystallites (Fig. 5 (a and b)), and the XPS result confirmed that the polysulfide was successfully captured by MoO2 in the form of SO4 2− and S2O3 2−, indicating a strong chemical interaction between the sulfur species and the MoO2 component. The charge transfer resistances of the Li-S cells with the MoO2/CNF interlayer and the pristine separator were measured to be 38.73 and 228.43 Ω, respectively. CV curves showed that the reduction–oxidation peaks of the battery with MoO2/CNF interlayer had an obvious shift, indicating a low potential polarization and a good cell reversibility (Fig. 5(c and d)). The result verified that the porous and conductive CNF network accelerated the transfer of both ions and electrons. Benefit from the synergetic contribution of both MoO2 and CNF scaffold, a high initial discharge capacity of 1366 mAh g−1 was achieved at the current density of 0.42 mA cm−2, with a 1006 mAh g−1 capacity retention over 150 cycles. Ding et al. developed a separator with TiO2 quantum dot modified CNT interlayer in consideration that there is a strong chemical interaction between TiO2 and polysulfide [94]. Guo et al. prepared a Ti4O7/CNF composite film to serve as the freestanding interlayer [95]. These two kinds of titanium oxides and carbon composites both demonstrated effective physical blocking and chemical absorption to polysulfide. The former group confirmed that the TiO2/CNT modified separator can well accommodate the expansion of electrode during the charge/discharge process, alleviate the transmission and loss of active materials. While Guo's group claimed the sulfur distribution in Ti4O7/CNF interlayer was more uniform than that in TiO2/CNF. Nevertheless, both groups reported Li-S batteries with ultra-long cycle lives and high rate capabilities in the cases of titanium oxide–carbon composite interlayers were used. A trilayer separator of Al2O3/CNT/PP is prepared by casting Al2O3 nanoparticles and CNT dispersion onto a commercial PP separator [90]. Charge/discharge measurement revealed that in the same cycling condition, the discharge capacity increased with the separator in the order of PP < Al2O3/PP < Al2O3/CNT/PP (Fig. 5(e)). The Al2O3 layer in the trilayer separator not only enhanced the thermal stability and electrolyte intake of the separator but also provided a good shielding effect for CNT from penetrating in case of the CNT was directly coated. The CNT in the trilayer separator acted as a porous and conductive matrix for capturing the polysulfide species physically, as well as reducing the charge transfer resistance of the sulfur cathode (Fig. 5(f)). The combination of Al2O3 and CNT on the routine PP separator together afforded a superior electrochemical performance. Metal oxide supported with graphene-related substrate has also been investigated recently. For instance, Xiao et al. coated TiO2/graphene on the cathode side membrane using a blade-coating machine [96]. This thin interlayer accounted for only ~7.8 wt% of the whole cathode and had only a slight influence on the energy density of the whole device. EDS results showed that the uniformly distributed TiO2 nanoparticles continuously captured the dissolved polysulfide while keeping the Li+/electrolyte transmission channels clear and open. Cells with TiO2/graphene film interlayer and porous CNT/S cathode exhibited a specific capacity of 1040 mAh g−1 over 300 cycles and an excellent rate performance with a low capacity decay of 0.01% per cycle for 1000 cycles. Impressively, this simple coating approach was also applicable to various carbon–sulfur composite cathodes. Hu et al. synthesized a SnO2/rGO composite film-shaped interlayer and overlaid it on one side of a commercial PP separator in Li-S batter y [97]. The SnO2/rGO composite and PVDF binder were mixed in the weight ratio of 9:1. The interlayer decreased the charge transfer resistance and trapped the soluble lithium polysulfide in the batteries. As a result, after 200 cycles at 1 C, the battery delivered a reversible capacity of 734 mAh g−1, which maintained at 602 and 501 mAh g−1 at the rates of 2 C and 3 C, respectively. The superior battery performance was ascribed to the enhanced physical interaction between polysulfide and the SnO2/rGO networks, as well as the high electrical conductivity of the graphene matrix that promoted the redox reaction process and the utilization of sulfur materials, especially at the high charge/discharge rates. Metal oxides with other carbon-based structural supports were also reported. For example, a pyrolyzed bacterial cellulose (PBC) decorated with tin oxide (SnO2) nanoparticles were developed as the interlayer for Li-S battery [98]. The cellulose-based composite was fabricated by a wet-chemical method accompanied by a high-temperature sintering treatment as shown in Fig. 6 (a). The resultant SnO2-PBC was nontoxic and consisted of biocompatible extra-polymeric carbon materials. The corresponding SEM image is giving in Fig. 6(b). In this research, Li2S/carbon composite was used as a cathode with 50wt% of Li2S. Fig. 6(c) shows that the as-designed SnO2-PBC interlayer enabled the cathode to deliver an initial discharge capacity of 812 mAh g−1, which gradually reduced to 468 mAh g−1 over 100 cycles at 0.1 C. However, the battery with only PBC interlayer or without interlayer revealed both inferior initial capacity and cycling stability. It was attributed to the improved electrode–electrolyte interface and enhanced charged transfer kinetics after the insertion of the SnO2-PBC interlayer, which had a high conductivity and a strong affinity to the dissolved polysulfide. Metal sulfide or nitride are other metal-based inorganics that have been attempted in the interlayers of Li-S batteries that can directly intervene in the process of polysulfide diffusion [99–104]. The state-of-the-art progress on metal sulfide/nitride-based Li-S battery interlayers is briefly introduced below. For example, nanostructured Co9S8 has been long regarded as an effective material to suppress the shuttle effect of polysulfide through high physical and chemical trapping ability [105]. Recently, professor Manthiram’s group designed a vertical Co9S8 nano-array modified PP separator to serve as a cathodic interlayer [106]. Due to the hollow structure, polar surface, and high electrical conductivity, Co9S8 array not only physically and chemically blocked the active material within the cathode region, but also accelerated the redox conversion of polysulfide in the liquid phase. As a result, the charge transfer resistance of fresh cells with Co9S8-PP separator was low and the utilization of active material was improved. Chemical adsorption between Co9S8 and polysulfide was confirmed by FTIR and XPS measurements. Thus, even with a pure sulfur cathode (areal density of 5.6 mg cm−2), the Co9S8-PP separator afforded the battery a high initial capacity of 1385 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, and a retention of 1190 mAh g−1 over 200 cycles. Moreover, a high capacity of 530 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles was obtained that demonstrated a promising application for long-term cycling battery at high charge/discharge densities. Employing bimetallic sulfides with the proper stoichiometric ratio is a prominent strategy to develop effective interlayers. For example, Huang et al. used carbon paper (CP) as the substrate to load Co/Fe bimetallic sulfides (CFS) via a solvothermal method [107]. Results showed that the stoichiometric ratio of CoCl2:FeCl2:thioacetamide of 2:1:3 offered the CFS product a single pyrite phase and the best chemisorption ability toward polysulfide. The CFS/CP-based interlayer had the advantage of exposing more active sites and providing more open channels for electrolyte wetting (Fig. 7 (a)). More importantly, the strong polarity of CFS enhanced the kinetics of polysulfide conversion as convinced by the Tafel plot in Fig. 7(b and c). The CFS/CP showed lower slopes in both oxidation and reduction processes comparing with those of pristine CP, indicating the excellent catalytic ability and the rapid catalytic kinetics for a sulfur-sulfide redox reaction. Therefore, the rational design of the CFS-based interlayer achieved a robust catalytic effect and a stable cycling performance with a capacity loss ratio of 0.11% per cycle over 400 cycles. Inserting a metal nitride-based freestanding interlayer which could offer a polar surface is also effective in polysulfide trapping and conversion. To give an example, Li et al. employed a nitride Co2N/Ni3N that derived from layered double hydroxide as an interlayer [109]. They found that a chemically stable passivation layer with a hydrophilic metal-O group was formed on the surface of the interlayer, which exerted a strong binding interaction with the polysulfide. The bonding being active sulfur with Co and Ni atoms was confirmed by XPS measurement. What’s more, the space between the nitride nanoparticles helped retain electrolyte and enhanced the electron exchange rate. The interaction between Co2N/Ni3N and polysulfide afforded the battery an initial discharge capacity of 764.6 mAh g−1 and a retention of 477.5 mAh g−1 for 800 cycles. The mixture of metal nitride, conductive agent, and binder can also be directly coated on the separator as an integrated interlayer. For example, Zhang et al. prepared InN nanowire as a coating layer by annealing In2O3 powder under the NH3 atmosphere [110]. Results showed that the crystal structure of InN was preserved even after 1000 cycles of charging/discharging and an excellent rate capability and high cycling stability were achieved. To r ealize the efficient conversion of immobilized polysulfide, Zhou et al. designed a twinborn TiN-TiO2 heterostructure and coated it onto a commercial PP separator (Fig. 7(d)) [108]. The highly adsorptive TiO2 strongly trapped polysulfide, which then smoothly diffused across the nanometer-sized interface to the TiN part. Meanwhile, the polar conductor TiN promoted fast nucleation and rapid conversion of polysulfide into the insoluble product. Therefore, an endurable capacity of 927 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles was obtained under 0.3 C. More impressively, at high sulfur loadings of 3.1 and 4.3 mg cm−2, the respective capacity retentions of 73% and 67% were achieved over 2000 cycles. Table 3 shows that various kinds of metal-based inorganic interlayers have been proved effective in trapping the polysulfide and promoting the electrochemical process of Li-S batteries recently. However, concrete criteria that evaluate the vital features of these interlayers still need to be set up. For instance, Liang et al. found that metal oxide with redox potential between 2.4 and 3.05 V can promote polythionate formation, which will finally contribute to the better electrochemical performance of the battery [121]. While there is no clear definition involving the exact potential window that claims the formation of polythionate in the electrochemical process. With more evaluation criterions being established, the application of interlayers in Li-S batteries would be more practical and reliable. Comparing with metal oxide, metal sulfide or nitride-based interlayers have demonstrated attractive advantages in capturing and accelerating the redox conversion of polysulfide intermediates, as well as promoting the electrochemical performance of batteries. The binding energy of the metal-sulfur bond is a fundamental criterion for a potential candidate, while the Tafel plot of redox conversion could provide convincing proof for the charge/discharge process. The combination of both metal oxides and metal sulfides/nitrides to give out a well-designed heterostructure opens a way for high performance Li-S batteries with ultralong cycle lives, and that would be a promising direction for future study. 2.4 Metal-organic frameworks Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) that consisting of metal centers and organic ligands are generally utilized as the precursors to fabricate different materials including metal oxide and porous carbon. The MOF derived porous carbon structure usually has a dramatically high surface area up to 4000 m2 g−1 and controllable pore size distribution [1]. Therefore, MOFs and their derivatives are promising candidates for energy storage and conversion usage, and various applications have been initiated in the fields of new type batteries, fuel cells, solar cells, and supercapacitors, etc. [122,123] Herein, in this part, individual MOF with different kinds metal center as well as MOF composite interlayers employed in Li-S batteries will be discussed. For example, Chen’s group adopted a new MOF structure, Ni3(2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene)2 (Ni3(HITP)2) to modify PP separator for trapping polysulfide. The MOF was fabricated by adding concentrated NH4OH to NiCl2 and 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaaminotriphenylene hexahydrochloride (HATP·6HCl) aqueous solution, followed by continuous stirring and low-temperature heating [124]. The metal center of MOF enhanced the affinity to polysulfide due to the Lewis acid-base interaction, and the resultant MOF-based coating interlayer showed an intrinsic microporous structure with hydrophilic polarity and high conductivity that significantly boosted the kinetics of the electrochemical reaction in the cell. As a result, the Li-S battery with this MOF coated interlayer delivered considerable capacities of 1220.1 and 800.2 mAh g−1 at the rates of 0.1 C and 2 C, respectively. To further improve the cycling performance, Dae Hee Lee and co-workers synthesized Ni-based MOF (Ni-MOF) particles and MWCNT composite, then coated onto a polyethylene (PE) separator as the integrated interlayer (Fig. 8 (a and b)) [125]. The soluble lithium polysulfide was supposed to be immobilized by the interaction between the coordinately unsaturated Ni2+ site in Ni-MOF structure and lithium polysulfide, while the MWCNT acted as a physical barrier to retard the diffusion of polysulfide and enhanced the electronic conductivity of trapped sulfur species. In this case, the cycling stability was improved by introducing the MOF/MWCNT coating interlayer. One can see that after 300 cycles at 0.2 C, the capacity decay was ~200 (maintaining at 1183 mAh g−1) and ~450 mAh g−1 with and without the MOF/MWCNT modification, respectively (Fig. 8(c and d)). EIS measurements further demonstrated that the combination of Ni-MOF and MWCNT in the interlayer effectively restrained the soluble polysulfide in the cathodic side, reutilized the active materials, resulted into a reduced internal resistance in the electrochemical process. A cerium-based MOF (Ce-MOF) combined with CNT was proposed by Hong et al. to serve as a separator coating material in Li-S battery [126]. The fabrication process of Ce-MOF/CNT composite including the use of benzene-1, 3, 5-tricarboxylic acid, ceric ammonium nitrate and activated CNT. The resultant Ce-MOF/CNT material was coated on separator as a functional interlayer. Fig. 8(e) shows a schematic illustration of the Li-S battery with a Ce-MOF/CNT catalysis interlayer. By this means, the contact resistance between the sulfur cathode and the separator was significantly reduced as confirmed by the EIS result. Thus, Ce-MOF/CNT composite greatly enhanced the battery’s rate performance in the range of 0.2~4C-rate (Fig. 8(f)). Furthermore, the MOF based coating layers with large surface area and highly dispersed, metal-catalytically active sites effectively improved the adsorption and catalytic conversion of polysulfide. Thus, at the sulfur loading of 2.5 mg cm−2, a high initial capacity of 1021.8 mAh g−1 at 1 C was achieved, which slowly reduced to 838.8 mAh g−1 over 800 cycles with a low decay rate of 0.022% per cycle, far better than the cycling stability of Li-S cells without MOF interlayers (Fig. 8(g)). A sulfonated MOF material Zr6O4(OH)4(BDC)6 (BDC refers to 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), named as UiO-66-S, was combined with Nafion to fabricate a composite interlayer to improve the cycling stability, rate capability and energy efficiency of Li-S battery [127]. The UiO-66-S/Nafion hybrid was coated onto a PE separator by vacuum filtration. Results showed that the Li-S cells containing UiO-66-S/Nafion hybrid layer possessed the lowest solution resistance and charge transfer resistance of 0.6 and 123.0 Ω, respectively, suggesting an improved kinetic process promoted by MOF intervention. The sulfonated MOF derivative was proved that it could enhance the electrostatic repulsion with polysulfide and ionic conduction [128]. Moreover, the UiO-66-S/Nafion hybrid layer coated separator showed a smaller pore size than the dimension of polysulfide that will further restrict the shuttling of polysulfide. Thus, the shuttling of polysulfide in Li-S cell with UiO-66-S/Nafion interlayer was greatly inhibited and the redox kinetics of sulfur conversion was improved. Exploring MOF-based polysulfide trapper and conversion catalyzer is a fast-growing field. It is believed that strong Lewis acid and base interaction between metal node and polysulfide will turn MOF into efficient polysulfide trapper. Highly ordered structure of MOF could help guide the homogenous flux of Li+ ion, rendering it a promising candidate to avoid the previously required anode modification while still maintaining an excellent battery performance [129–131]. Therefore, substantial efforts have yet to be focused on this area. 3 Anodic interlayer Anodic interlayer refers to a layer of certain material coated on the anodic side of the separator, as well as freestanding layer inserted at the between the anode and the separator. The lithium anode faces severe problems such as random lithium deposition and the growth of lithium dendrite which might break through the separator, resulting in the direct contact of cathode and anode. Therefore, guiding the relatively uniform deposition of lithium and preventing the separator from severe damage caused by lithium dendrite are important objectives of anodic interlayer in Li-S batteries [132]. Generally, the strategy to deal with the above problem is adding certain interlayers to suppress the growth of dendrite by reducing the local current, controlling the homogeneous and stable Li+ ion flux. For example, Ye et al. fabricated a superstructure consisted of modularly-assembled carbon black nanoparticles (MAXC) and coated onto a commercial separator toward the anodic side [133]. During the charge/discharge process, the growth of Li dendrite was suppressed as manifested by the small diameter pinholes formed among the MAXC structure. Thus, the MAXC interlayer not only facilitated the adsorption and redox of soluble polysulfide, but also promoted the uniform deposition of Li+ ions and the stability of SEI formation, leading to a compact and stable Li metal anode. The Li-S battery with a MAXC interlayer delivered a high areal capacity of 909 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles with a high sulfur loading of 5.3 mg cm−2. A freestanding carbon-based thin-film interlayer carbonized from silk fibroin nanofiber was also employed between the anode and separator of Li-S battery [134]. Results showed that the interwoven network and microporous structure of the interlayer effectively hindered the formation of lithium dendrite and protected the Li metal from corrosion during the electrochemical process. Polar Al2O3 nanoparticle-based interlayer was coated onto the anodic side of separator in the Li-S battery as reported by Hwang’s group [135]. The addition of Al2O3 provided another medium for scavenging polysulfide and suppressing their migration to the anode when the sulfur loading density was high. Moreover, the excellent mechanical stability of the Al2O3 layer not only protected the composite separator from damage after long-time cycling, but also effectively suppressed the growth of dendritic Li metal and minimized the risk of internal short circuit. However, the insulating nature of Al2O3 retarded the ion transfer speed and lengthened the ion migration path in the separator, led to lower discharge capacities especially at high current densities. While Paolella et al. revealed that the conductive anodic interlayer might mitigate this drawback by using nano-platinum coating on the separator [136]. In this work, a commercial PP separator was sputtered by a thin layer of platinum, which protected the surface of lithium from polysulfide-reduction induced degradation and minimized the polysulfide shuttle effect. As a result, the battery with platinum film interlayer demonstrated an increased capacity and enhanced retention at high current densities compared with the routine Celgard separator. CNT film-based anodic interlayer has also been investigated by inserting a CNT film on both the anodic side and the cathodic side as reported in Xie’s group (Fig. 9 (a)) [37]. By this design, the compact CNT film acted not only as a physical barrier to prevent chemical reactions between polysulfide and Li metal anode, but also as a powerful shield to suppress the growth of Li dendrite. During the electrochemical process, the CNT film toward the anodic side has a large surface area and good electrical conductivity that could reduce the local current density, leading to a slow and uniform deposition of Li on the anode. Therefore, the rate capability of the battery was greatly improved as shown in Fig. 9(b). Moreover, the resulted battery with sulfur/graphene cathode and the CNT film interlayer delivered an initial capacity of 808 mAh g−1 and a remaining capacity of 590 mAh g−1 over 150 cycles, with a Coulombic efficiency of almost 100%. MOF structures with rich porosity, nanometer-size cavity, and high surface areas have been demonstrated effective as the Li-S battery cathodic interlayers as discussed above. However, they can also be employed at the anodic side and coated on the separator to mitigate polysulfide diffusion. For example, Li et al. reported four different types of MOF materials that were used as the anodic interlayer (Fig. 9(c)) [137]. Results showed that different chemical compositions and variations in the sizes and shapes of MOF particles rendered the resultant battery with different electrochemical behaviors (Fig. 9(d–h)). The Cu ions in the HKUST cluster would react with the sulfur material to deteriorate the shuttling and loss of polysulfide, reduce the Coulombic efficiency due to the problem of chemical stability. On the other hand, the pore size in MOF was not the only predominant factor inhibiting the polysulfide migration. Because the diffusion can easily proceed through the grain boundary channels. In general, the cycling performance of batteries with different MOF-based anodic interlayers are summarized in Fig. 9(h). An empirical conclusion is that the higher the stability of the MOF and the denser the assembly structure, the more resistant of the interlayer to polysulfide. As an anodic interlayer, carbon material and metal compound with good electrical conductivity can effectively promote electron/ion transfer, reduce local current, inhibit the generation of lithium dendrite, and protect lithium anode by forming a stable SEI film. A porous, dense and stable MOF structure derived interlayer is an effective intermediate to prevent the polysulfide from traveling through. However, the main issue in the anode side is considered to be the fast and uneven growth of dendrite. Anodic interlayer that can address the dynamic process of dendrite evolution and polysulfide diffusion is always welcome. There are also some routes reported using composite anodes to confine the locally rapid growth of Li dendrite that also afforded the cell with higher Coulombic efficiency and better cycling stability [138]. However, these are usually not considered as interlayers in the field of Li-S batteries, and not included in the review. In general, some basic rules should be kept in mind when trying to find proper anodic interlayers: (i) Effectively suppress the growth of Li dendrite, (ii) possess acceptable Li+ ion conductivity, (iii) no need of high-cost preparation method, (iv) highly stable in the inside condition of Li-S batteries. 4 Novel separators Membrane-shaped separators are basic barriers in cell construction to avoid electric short circuits. Except for commercial PP separator, coating, or inserting interlayers between the cathode and anode that can effectively reduce the diffusion of polysulfide, enhance the utilization of active materials or facilitate the transport of charges are also desirable. Recently, novel separators made from polyvinylidene fluoride-hexafluoropropyle [139], glass fiber [140] and Nafion-PP [141], etc. have attracted substantial interests. The research on new separator material is centered on reducing the shuttle effect of polysulfide by adjusting the pore size and promoting the transfer of electrons/ions through structural designing. For example, Zhu et al. reported a novel bifunctional double-layer rGO-PVDF/PVDF composite separator [142]. The PVDF nanofiber membrane was prepared by an electrospinning method with an interconnected fiber morphology (Fig. 10 (a)). Subsequently, an rGO-PVDF solution was directly deposited onto the PVDF nanofiber membrane (Fig. 10(b)). After thermal treatment at 80 °C for 24 h, the present rGO-PVDF/PVDF separator maintained its original shape, while an obvious shrinkage was observed in the control PP separator. Due to the widespread nano and micropores throughout the PVDF networks, the rGO-PVDF/PVDF separator ensured a fast Li+ ions transfer and a large electrolyte uptake. Two separators with different thickness of 75 ± 5 μm (rGO-PVDF/PVDF-1) and 95 ± 5 μm (rGO-PVDF/PVDF-2) were employed in Li-S batteries for comparison. The resultant cells showed improved discharge capacities of 1040 and 1322 mAh g−1, respectively, comparing to the 703 mAh g−1 obtained from cells with pure PP separator (Fig. 10(c)). Moreover, with the rGO-PVDF/PVDF separator, the resultant battery revealed a greatly enhanced rate capability in the range of 0.2~2C (Fig. 10(d)). Furthermore, after 200 cycles at 1 C, the surface of PP separator was covered by plenty of S-related species (Fig. 10(e)), while there were still open pores within the rGO-PVDF/PVDF membrane (Fig. 10(f)), which will continue to facilitate the transportation of Li+ ions in the electrochemical process. The significantly enhanced cycling and rate performance were attributed to two functions that accompanied with the novel separators. First, the porous PVDF nanofiber layer provided good thermal stability and maintained the structural integrity of the membrane. Second, the conductive rGO-PVDF layer retarded the diffusion of polysulfide and ensured a fast transfer of ions. Sustainable and highly porous polyacrylonitrile (PAN)/GO nanofiber composite separator was reported in Li-S battery (Fig. 10(g)) [143]. With the oxygen-containing functional groups in GO, the shuttling of polysulfide was effectively minimized. As shown in Fig. 10(h), the initial discharge capacity for cells with PP and PAN/GO separators were 781 and 987 mAh g−1, respectively. After 100 cycles, the later remained at a higher capacity of ~600 mAh g−1. Moreover, during the rate performance test, cells with PAN/GO separator exhibited the slowest capacity decay as the current density increased (Fig. 10(i)). For example, at 0.2, 0.5, and 1 C, the corresponding capacities were 699, 591, and 448 mAh g−1, respectively, while the cells with PP separator were 445, 382, and 303 mAh g−1, respectively. The cycling and rate properties improvement was attributed to the synergistic effect including the porous structure and good wettability of the PAN/GO nanofiber, as well as the physical and chemical barrier effect of the PAN molecules. More importantly, this work provided a novel strategy for Li-S batteries with GO-based polymer membranes as the new separator materials. Another notable work involving unique separators was conducted by Yu et al. [145]. In this research, the traditional PP membrane was replaced with a lithiated Nafion membrane which acted as both the cation-selective electrolyte and the non-electrically conductive separator (Fig. 10(j)). Moreover, a thin CNF film was used as the cathodic interlayer and a Li2S6-filled CNF as the cathode. By this design, the SO3Li+ group on the surface of the polymeric separator could transfer Li+ cation during the electrochemical process. Comparing with the traditional porous PP separator, the diffusion of long-chain polysulfide was significantly suppressed as manifested by the remaining transparent of the battery solvent. As a result, the sulfur utilization was improved and the cycling stability of the cell was greatly enhanced. Taking advantage of the highly ordered three-dimensional channel structure, MOF-structured materials were also employed as the separators of Li-S batteries. For example, Cu3(BTC)2 (HKUST-1) that contained highly ordered micropores with a size window of ~0.9 nm was applied to construct the MOF/GO composite separator [146]. Thus, the cooperative combination of MOF and GO not only sieved Li+ ions while blocking the permeation of polysulfide, but also rendered the separator remarkable mechanical stability. Therefore, without complicated synthesis or chemical modification of the cathode material, the battery with a MOF/GO separator exhibited an impressively low capacity decay rate at 0.019% per cycle over 1500 cycles. Furthermore, there was no capacity fading observed after the initial 100 cycles. Reducing the pore size in the insulating separator to suppress the migration of polysulfide while allowing the Li+ ions transport has been recently realized in Manthiram’s group [144]. In this report, a polymer with the intrinsic nanoporosity (PIN) was used to fill the micrometer-scale pores of normal PP separator. Molecular dynamic simulation results showed that the pore size of PIN is less than 2 nm. With a fast dipping of PP separator in the PIN solution, a composite PIN-PP separator was obtained while the membrane thickness was almost the same. However, PIN filler prevented the migration of soluble polysulfide species authenticated by the penetration test (Fig. 10(k and l)). As a result, the Li-S battery with PIN-PP separator maintained a capacity of ~750 mAh g−1 with 100% Coulombic efficiency over 200 cycles at 0.2 C. In contrast, as a routine PP separator was employed, the capacity loss exceeded 95% after 200 cycles. Thus, the battery’s cycling stability was greatly enhanced. Moreover, the thin PIN-PP separator allowed the Li-S battery to be operated at high sulfur loadings of >2 mg cm−2 while still maintaining electrochemical performance. An ideal separator should not only improve the capacity, cycling stability, and rate performance of Li-S battery, but also ensure the safety of the whole device. To prevent the collapse of cell construction, thermal and chemical stability are also an essential requirement for the separator. Furthermore, separators should have large electrolyte uptake and good permeability for Li+ ions to guarantee a fast electrochemical kinetic. However, since one of the main reasons for separator breakdown is the puncturing from lithium dendrite, the significant effort can be devoted to exploring the fundamental solutions to prevent the growth of lithium dendrite from the perspective of the separator, especially towards the anode side. 5 Prospects and outlooks In conclusion, we have summarized the development of different interlayers and separators employed in Li-S batteries recently. The application of a cathodic interlayer aims to restrain the shuttle effect of polysulfide, to promote the conversion of polysulfide and to protect the electrode. While anodic interlayer mainly intends to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrite. With these barrier layers, the overall electrochemical properties, including capacity, cycling stability, and rate capability. of the resultant battery are enhanced. For cathodic interlayer, the combination of physical blocking and chemical absorption is more effective compared with the case of a single contribution is introduced. Some newly developed materials beyond the discussed categories are also worth researching, such as the black-phosphorus [147] and delaminated Ti3C2 MXene [148] that have been demonstrated effective in improving the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Nevertheless, introducing interlayers into the battery should always meet the following requirements: (i) facile fabrication process, (ii) no penetrating risk to the separator, (iii) good electrolyte affinity, (iv) high Li+ ion penetration efficiency, (v) as thin and lightweight as possible to avoid evident decrease of energy density, (vi) excellent thermal, chemical, and mechanical stability. At present, the research of Li-S battery in the laboratory has been quite in-depth, and preliminarily application in some conceptual product has been seen. However, comparing with the button battery that commonly studied in the research, the volume of the electrode of a practical battery is much larger, which makes the volume expansion problem more obvious. In addition, with the increase of electrode area, more polysulfide intermediates and severe lithium corrosion might happen, leading to the designing of interlayer and separator more challenging. Fortunately, efforts aiming to solve these problems have seen appealing progress in the research lab. On the other hand, enhance the energy density and reduce the safety risk of Li-S battery are also important before practical applications, which requires high sulfur loading and low electrolyte content in the real battery. While the increase of sulfur and decrease of the electrolyte leads to the concentration of polysulfide greatly increased, which not only exacerbates the shuttle effect of polysulfide, but also enhances the viscosity of the electrolyte, resulting to more serious kinetic problems. In this condition, an additional requirement should be considered when designing the interlayer. For example, it should be very thin but mechanically strong enough. The interlayer should have good wettability with electrolyte and, do not consume electrolyte in the electrochemical process. Moreover, the interlayer is expected to not only accommodate as much as sulfur species, but also provide fast ions/electrons transfer channels to catalytically promote the polysulfide conversion. However, one might see that the widespread commercialization of Li-S battery is still on the way due to the unsettled scientific and technical issues. In addition to the reasonable design of nanostructured electrode, innovative electrolyte formulation and, effective scaffold construction, advancements in interlayer and separator technologies are also important to promote the practical application process. Therefore, the present review of the additional barrier layers provides a timely reference for the future development of the Li-S battery, as well as other rechargeable batteries. We hope this summary be useful to the field of energy storage and conversion community. Deming Zhu is currently an undergraduate student at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hefei University of Technology. His research interests focus on the interlayer in Li-S batteries and the catalyst for Zn-air batteries. Tao Long is currently a master student in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hefei University of Technology. He received his B. E. degree from Anhui Polytechnic University in 2018. His research interests focus on the electrode materials for Li-S batteries and supercapacitors. Bin Xu is currently a master student in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hefei University of Technology. He received his bachelor’s degree in polymer materials and engineering from Wanxi University in 2019. Currently, his research interests focus on carbon materials and their energy-related applications. Yixin Zhao is currently pursuing his master degree at the School of Materials Engineering, Hefei University of Technology. He studied material physics at Anhui University and got his bachelor’s degree in 2019. Currently, his research interest is on the cathode materials for Li-S batteries. Haitao Hong is currently an undergraduate student at Hefei University of Technology. He received several awards including university scholarships, honorable mention of Interdisciplinary Contest in Modeling, and so on. His research interests focus on the mathematical modeling, sensors, electronic information engineering, etc. Ruijie Liu is currently an undergraduate student at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hefei University of Technology. His research interests including the preparation of functional nanomaterials, actuators and lithium batteries. Fancheng Meng is currently a research associate professor in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hefei University of Technology. He received his Ph.D. degree (2013) in physical chemistry from Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He has published more than 30 peer-reviewed journal papers and his research interests focus on the fabrication of carbon-based materials for smart and energy storage devices. Jiehua Liu received his Ph.D. degree from Nanyang Technological University in 2011. He has published over 50 journal papers and is currently a full professor in Hefei University of Technology. His group mainly focuses on the design, synthesis and performance improvement of high-performance energy storage materials and their applications for batteries and supercapacitors.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have great potential in next-generation energy storage due to its high theoretical specific capacity and energy density. However, there are several challenges to the practical application of Li-S batteries including the growth of lithium dendrites and the shuttle effect of polysulfide. Introducing interlayeres (freestanding or coated on the separator) is an effective approach to reduce these obstacles and improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. In this review, we briefly summarize the interlayer materials and structures modified on both cathodic and anodic sides including (i) carbon-based materials, (ii) polymers, (iii) inorganic metal compounds, (iv) metal–organic frameworks, as well as (v) the novel separators in recent years. We also systematically address the fabrication processes, assembling methods, and functions of interlayers for enhancing the performance of Li-S batteries. Furthermore, the prospects and outlooks of the future development of advanced interlayers and separators are also presented.
